I faced two issues.

### 1. Ip address for local environment

In Docker for Mac environment, there is no docker network interface.
That means there is no 172.17.0.0/32 network.

This is because Docker for Mac takes advantage of xhyve VM.
In xhyve VM, there might be above network.
But in OS X side, there is no such network, it just do the port-forwarding to xhyve VM.

So current local setup inventory file does not work for "Docker for Mac".
I changed ip address of local inventory file as follow.

```
; db group is only used if db_provider is CouchDB
[db]
10.64.131.142 ansible_connection=local
```


### 2. Upper case in db name

While proceeding "wipe.yml" step, I noticed that if there any upper case in "ansible_user_id" or "ansible_hostanme", the step fails.

It can be easily resolved by changing them manually to lower case.
However, it will be better to make them to lower case during the ansible deployment steps because such case can be frequently occurred.

With "Docker for Mac", docker remote api is not available by default.
It is listed as known issue in docker.com.
https://docs.docker.com/docker-for-mac/troubleshoot/#/known-issues

Many users are wondering why this is missing.
https://forums.docker.com/t/remote-api-with-docker-for-mac-beta/15639/7

Anyway, the workaround is proxying the unix socket using socat command.
```
docker run -d -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock -p 4243:2375 bobrik/socat TCP4-LISTEN:2375,fork,reuseaddr UNIX-CONNECT:/var/run/docker.sock
```

Suggestions from the dev list (credit: Felix Meschberger):

- [x] As for the status codes, 404/Not Found for non-existing actions rather than 400/Bad Request. (https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1715/commits/30e706bcce90b8e14e2cc45be01aea04aa63a009)
- [x] And 404 as well for the case of the action not being available anonymously. (https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1715/commits/30e706bcce90b8e14e2cc45be01aea04aa63a009)
- [x] Missing support for the requested content type could be 406/Not Acceptable (or also 404/Not Found). (https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1715/commits/c3ca60966f21556af72ea32e29621a24aa292111)
- [x] Consider using the an extension in the action such as …/my-action.html to indicate the Content-Type to represent the resource as. (https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1715/commits/c3ca60966f21556af72ea32e29621a24aa292111)

*EDIT:* Thinking about the last point (using an extension on the action to represent content-type), there are two parts relevant to the feature in this pr.

1. projecting a field from the JSON object that is the result of the action.
2. how to marshal the projected value (the content-type)

I conflated both: the property name implies also a convention for the marshaling. So using `html` reads `result.html` and turns it into the proper format. The suggestion from Felix makes it possible to disentangle the desired content-type and the property name to project. It could also then make it possible to project more than a top level property: the resource could be specified as a full path (of nested properties). As in: `https://openwhisk.host/experimental/web/ns/p/action.html/a/b/c.`

One issue with using "." as the separator is that it's also a legal character for action names. So we would mandate that if an extension is present it is a content-type and not an action name. Hence if the action is called `myaction.html` and to turn the response into `text/html` then the resource is `.../myaction.html.html/some-field`.

Implemented the above, and in addition:

- [x] pass the http method, path, and headers to the action. (https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1715/commits/888f54af12f412bd33af604139c96a761f99b5a9)
- [x] allow for composed projection. (https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/pull/1715/commits/4df17e8ad55e10f3b121475af598f4a6e0cfa4a3)

I may be inferring something incorrectly about your question - when openwhisk runs a user action, it does not build a new Docker image for that action.

The nodejs6action container is a generic base image. The user code is injected into the container later, and run, without modifying the base image. So modules that come in via zip file are not modified since they are not subject to a docker build.

While we can do this as part of v2 API, it's also possible to do as part of the current version with some nginx rewriting. Below I listed what the new API paths would look like for our current core API.

- _Let_ ns = namespace name or “\_”
- _Let_ pkg = package name or “default”
- _Let_ action = action name

### basic CRUD + activate operations for actions, triggers, rules

show below for actions but intended to be the same for triggers and rules:

#### read `get /api/v2/actions/ns/pkg/action`
#### create/update `put /api/v2/actions/ns/pkg/action`
#### delete `del /api/v2/actions/ns/pkg/action`
#### activate `post /api/v2/actions/ns/pkg/action`
#### list all actions in package `get /api/v2/actions/ns/pkg`
#### list all actions in all packages in namespace `get /api/v2/actions/ns`

#### questions and considerations
- get/put/del only exec "code" or "zip"? 
- want streaming for the “code” or “zip”, treat as attachments, subresource  
- support `?override`, `?createonly`, `?updateonly` for put
- list all actions in package can include bindings
- list all actions in all packages cannot easily includes bindings
- allow for action extensions for content type and projection for result path as in pr #1715?

### basic CRUD operations for packages

#### get package or binding `get /api/v2/packages/ns/pkg` (default not allowed) 
#### create/update package or binding `put /api/v2/actions/ns/pkg` (default not allowed, cannot be bound) 
#### delete package or binding `/api/v2/actions/ns/pkg` (default not allowed) 
#### list all packages and bindings in namespace `fet /api/v2/actions/ns`

### basic read operations for activations

#### get by id `/api/v2/activations/?id=`
#### get by name `/api/v2/activations/?name=`
#### get all activations for action `get /api/v2/activations/ns/pkg/action`
#### list all activations for actions in package `get /api/v2/activations/ns/pkg`
#### list all activations in all packages in namespace `get /api/v2/activations/ns`

#### questions and considerations
- get only logs, as rubresource?
- get only results, as subresource? 
- want streaming for the “logs” and the “results”, treat as attachments also
- support start, end, skip, limit on all list operations, return totals to allow pagination
- listing activations for packages may not include bindings

Comment from the peanut gallery:
How about making the load-balancer send test (dummy) payloads to each invoker that would get processed by the invoker by a specific system action that reports the ack *to* the load balancer. The advantage of such a setup would be that it is very close to measuring the _actual_ health of an invoker because if needs a healthy Kafka connection, healthy docker, etc.
Might require one "healthcheck" Kafka topic for each invoker so that this queue is always empty for the healthcheck (so that non-healthy invokers would not interfere with other parts of the system).

@michaelmarth that actually sounds like something we thought of as well:

We could use loadbalancer's existing data to enhance its health algorithm. We could examine the existing ACK messages for system errors and/or attach a timeout to an ACK of, say, 10 minutes (magic number, needs to be discussed) to also catch failing Kafka connections.

That way, the loadbalancer would know if an invoker is sick based on real live data and heuristics (i.e.: "Take an Invoker out if it has more than 5 invokes failed in 1 minute" or "Implement a exponential backoff for load dispatched to invoker X if requests fail").

@michaelmarth 👍 to your suggestion.

One thought that comes to my mind is that if Kafka becomes slow for some reason and the invoker can't consume messages fast enough to invoke the `health-check` action within `100ms` will the LB bring the execution down b/c of that ? In this case the Invoker is fine, but its Kafka dependency is not.

What if we keep this idea but instead of marking an invoker unhealthy b/c it's slow in invoking actions, create a priority queue for invokers in the LB pushing the slow invokers to the bottom and invoke actions using the ones in the top ? we might end up with a _best effort QoS invocation logic_ in this way.

From the invoker's health status point of view one idea would be to make it dependent to the components the invoker manages:
* the machine it runs 
* the docker service running on that machine
* the containers it executed on that machine and how many resources they use
* etc

For cases when Kafka is not working as expected the question is if we wanna flag invokers as _unhealthy_ b/c of that. At that point we might be looking at scaling Kafka, adding more machines to run more invokers, reassigning partitions in Kafka and making it perform as expected. With the QoS based priority queue we could send new traffic to new invokers and wait for the slow ones to either recover or be taken out of service.
